abstract.p: By use of hand gesture recognition technology, traditional remote manufacturing networks can be operated by disabled people who lose the grasp ability. The surface electromyography (sEMG) network inference is critically important for revealing fundamental hand gesture processes, investigating sEMG functions, and understanding their relations. However, current hand gesture recognition methods using sEMG do not sufficiently consider the temporal behavior of this type of data and lack the capability to capture the complex nonlinear system dynamics. It is therefore imperative to have good methods to explore a more suitable choice, which can avoid the problems mentioned above. This paper presents a rapid prototyping manufacturing network with sEMG using recurrent hidden Markov models (RHMMs) and a particle swarm optimization (PSO) approach. It also provides high-level modeling, programming methods, and running results for this remote manufacturing network in terms of software and hardware. PSO is used to train the RHMM and determine the model parameters. Remote manufacturing is accomplished between the network monitor center and a number of sensor nodes by use of a sEMG sensor circuit and Winsock monitor sensors. Furthermore, it has such advantages as network wireless, low cost, and strong interaction and expansibility, and is easy to maintain and promote.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: Manufacturing is of great significance for modern society. The term may refer to a range of human activity, from handicraft to high tech, but it is most commonly adapted to persons who have grip activity. By means of hand gesture recognition technology, traditional remote manufacturing networks can be operated by disabled people who lose the grasp ability. Electromyography (EMG) is a technique for evaluating and recording the activation signal of muscles. Different hand movement patterns are in accordance with the different muscle contraction states. The surface electromyography (sEMG) monitor may bring a more universal method for the manufacturing field (Liu et al., 2008; Postelnicescu and Dragos, 2008).

Rapid prototyping (RP) technology can rapidly verify a design that enables engineers to catch mistakes earlier in the design process, to complete more design iterations in less time, and, thus, to bring products to market faster and with lower design costs. Nowadays, the research of network monitors based on RP technology has become a hot spot. The requirements are monitor wireless, program miniaturization, compatibility of interface, and expansibility of sensor network (Thomas, 1995; Lu, 2001).

A remote RP manufacturing network with sEMG using recurrent hidden Markov models (RHMMs) and the particle swarm optimization (PSO) approach is proposed in this paper. RHMMs can use their internal memory to process arbitrary sequences of inputs, which avoids the HMM problem of being easy to converge to local optimal solutions (Schambach, 2009; Zhu and Gao, 2010). Remote manufacturing is accomplished between the network monitor center and a number of sensor nodes by use of the sEMG sensor circuit and Winsock monitor sensors. Under this framework, sEMG interaction is explained through a connection weight matrix. Based on the fact that the sEMG signals under different gestures are usually sparsely connected, we present a PSO-based search algorithm to reveal constructions of sEMG signals under different gestures and explore possible sEMG interactions. PSO is used to train the RHMM and determine the model parameters.

sec.title: 2. The structure of the remote rapid prototyping manufacturing network
sec.p:
As shown in Figure 1, the structure of the remote RP manufacturing network is composed of a sEMG sensor circuit, a network monitor center, a wireless network, and sensor nodes. RP equipments and pickup cameras are components of sensor nodes. The network monitor center takes the responsibilities for sEMG signal collection by the sEMG sensor circuit and wireless network monitoring of sensor nodes. Figure 1.
Network model. sEMG: surface electromyography.

The remote RP manufacturing network has three dynamic processes. Firstly, four channel sEMG signals are collected by the sEMG sensor circuit. The features of sEMG signals are that they are calculated and classified by an optimized RHMM in order to identify sign language. The sign languages are used to monitor sensor nodes by the network monitor center. Secondly, sensor nodes are connected with the network monitor center through the wireless network, which is realized by a Time Division Synchronous Code Division Multiple Access (TD-SCDMA) wireless module. Users can adjust the focus of pickup cameras and the angle of pickup cameras with the monitoring platform. They can also monitor the concrete actions of RP equipments (Liu et al., 2008; Guo and Li, 2010, 2011).

sec.title: 3. Design of remote rapid prototyping manufacturing network
3.1. Identification of sign language
sec.p: Based on the fact that the sEMG signals under different gestures are usually sparsely connected, we present a PSO-based search algorithm to reveal constructions of sEMG signals under different gestures and explore possible sEMG interactions. The root mean square (RMS) features are obtained from sEMG signals. By optimizing the RHMM model, the hand gestures are recognized.

sec.title: 3.1.1. sEMG sensor circuit and signal acquisition
sec.p:
The sEMG signals are recorded by keeping four groups of silver cup electrodes (every group electrode has two electrodes) over the muscle belly, after the subjects undergo routine skin preparation and application of electrode gel. The ground electrode is attached over a suitable electrically inactive area and the subject is asked to contract the muscle voluntarily (see Figure 2). Figure 2.
Circuit of surface electromyography recording.

The main part of the circuit is four integrated circuit (IC) instrumentation amplifiers (INA 128, Texas Instruments). Each IC has two additional components to effect high-pass filtering. The IC is powered by two 9 V batteries connected in series, with the central common terminal being the circuit ground. The amplify gain is 400.

sec.title: 3.1.3. Particle swarm optimization
sec.p: Although the model has already been reported (Morales et al., 2009; Schambach, 2009), the difficulty of RHMM training limits its further application. Here, we propose using a different training strategy. PSO is used to determine the parameters of the RHMM. PSO consists of a swarm of particles, each of which represents a candidate solution. For each particle i, the particle's position with a uniformly distributed random vector xi moves in the multidimensional problem space with a corresponding particle's velocity vi. The basic idea of PSO is that each particle randomly finds a position around the search-space by updating itself with the social information gathered from other particles and its own memory (Zhu and Gao, 2010).

A batch mode for training is used, which means the parameter updates are performed after all input data points are presented to the model (Kennedy and Eberhart, 2001). The basic procedure of PSO-based RHMM training can be summarized as follows.

sec.title: 3.2. Achieve TD-SCDMA network environment
sec.p: Currently, Global Systems for Mobile Communication (GSMs) run only at 9.6 kbit/s, which cannot satisfy the user on high-speed wireless data business. However, TD-SCDMA can provide a maximum uplink speed of 384 kbps and a downlink speed of 2.8 Mbps, in theory. TD-SCDMA in practice offers a downlink speed of only about 30â60 kbps, which allows the multimedia services in wireless networks, for example, pictures, voice, and video, to become realistic.

The TD-SCDMA wireless monitor uses the TD-SCDMA wireless module of F1503 from Xiamen Four-Faith Communication Technology Co., Ltd in China. F1503 TD-SCDMA MODEM is based on the TD-SCDMA network and adopts the industrial wireless TD-SCDMA module. It supports Short Message Service (SMS), circuit switch data (CSD), and data function. It provides a MODEM host, a RS232 data cable, a power adapter, a certification card, a maintenance card, and an antenna.

The TD-SCDMA wireless monitor installs a standard modem that can meet the needs of equipment for the serial interface in Windows. Users connect the modem and personal computer (PC) with the shipped RS-232 cable and finish the setting of âPhone and Modem Optionsâ. Manufacturers choose âStandard Modem Typesâ and models choose âStandard 33600 bps Modemâ. Users set the Maximum Port Speed as 115,200 and write the Hayes command set (AT) command of ATâ+âCGDCONTâ=â1,âIPâ,âCMNETâ, where CMNET is the Access Point Name (APN) of China, in the dialog box of âExtra initializationâ. According to China Mobile, the number â*99***1#â used to help establish the TD-SCDMA connection request. Thus a new dial-up connection by using the modem given above is set up (Dong and Wu, 2009).

sec.title: 3.3. Client/server model design
sec.p: The manufacturing network adopts the C/S (client/server) model, that is, one host computer may operate another one in network. Ordinary computers, working stations, and so on are considered available in the realization of the client. As the core of the wireless sensor network (WSN), a client needs a fixed Internet Protocol (IP) address and a fixed port. Yet, a dynamic IP address is enough to server. The design of the TD-SCDMA sensor network can be achieved through the Winsock network programming interface. Winsock is a network programming interface in Windows. It is defined in reference to Sockets, which is popular in the Berkeley Software Distribution (BSD) UNIX system of U.C. Berkeley University.

The program of the server must run first. The server cannot receive the request of the client until it has finished transfer of the accept () function and has entered into the waiting state. If the program of the client runs firstly, the connect () function must return an error code and connection is unsuccessful. When the server and client establish connection, data will be written or read in sockets. After old sockets have closed, the server sends a request of the accept () function to the client again.

This manufacturing network transmits data by the protocol of Transmission Control Protocol (TCP). The working method is based on the IP. The IP address of the network monitor center (client) is 192.168.1.99. The port is 6000. According to the features of the manufacturing network and RP technology, the manufacturing network uses cases of CSocket, CSocketFile, and CArchive in VC++ 2008 to achieve remote communication and manufacturing.

sec.title: 4. Experiments for the remote manufacturing network
sec.p: Five volunteers have participated in the experiments. Each participant has tested one kind of flexion for 10 times. Electrodes are placed on the forearm muscles of brachioradialis, flexor digitorum superficialis (FDS), flexor carpi radialis (FCR) and flexor carpi ulnaris (FCU). sEMG signals have been recorded when the participant maintains specific finger flexions of middle finger flexion, all fingers flexion, and so on. The flexions are performed without any resistance. These flexions are chosen as they are very convenient and easily reproducible by the participant. The order of the flexions is arbitrary and each flexion is maintained for about 8â10 s to record sEMG; the duration of each run of the experiment is about 60 s.

In order to indicate the correctness of the proposed RHMM/PSO, experiments have been conducted by comparing with algorithms of the neural network and the hidden Markov model. Figure 5 makes it clear that users can monitor the concrete actions of RP equipments by sEMG signals. Figure 5.

Take the negative direction turn of the roller as an example. When users press the button of negative direction turn of the roller in the monitor panel, the sensor node (client) sends a command to the server and the server accepts the command of the client. Thus, the action of the roller in the RP equipment is monitored directly. At the same time, the successful information through the information dialog is informed to the client.

sec.title: 5. Conclusions
sec.p: As an interdisciplinary technology, RP promotes the development of the relevant technology and industries. Biosignal processing has brought pattern recognition and intelligent manufacturing a creative and novel method. The RHMM and PSO approaches are presented in this paper. Under this framework, convergence of local optimal solutions and fit with sparsely connected time-series data are solved by adjusting disturbed extremum. TD-SCDMA has such advantages as low cost, no restrictions, access at high speed, always online, and charging according to flow.

This RP manufacturing network has accomplished remote manufacturing between the network monitor center and a number of sensor nodes by use of the sEMG sensor circuit and Winsock monitor sensors. Furthermore, it has such advantages as network wireless, low cost, and strong interaction and expansibility, and is easy to maintain and promote.

For the rapid prototyping manufacturing network, we consider several further extensions. Firstly, time delay is an important property of the sEMG recognition model. Flexible Neural Trees (FNT) is a fuzzy model that is generated and evolved based on the pre-defined simple instruction sets. It can solve highly structure dependent problems of the Artificial Neural Network (ANN) (Chen and Abraham, 2009). Secondly, the model of RHMM+PSO is easy to result in complicated computation. FNT method also avoids complicated computation and the inconvenience of circuit connection.
